skill.name: algorithmic-art
skill.description: Creating algorithmic art using p5.js with seeded randomness and interactive parameter exploration. Use this when users request creating art using code, generative art, algorithmic art, flow fields, or particle systems. Create original algorithmic art rather than copying existing artists' work to avoid copyright violations.

security_audit.summary: This is an official skill from the referenced repository and is pre-reviewed. No security issues were identified in this minimal audit.

content.value_statement: You need a clear process to turn ideas into generative art. This skill builds a philosophy and a ready HTML artifact with seeded, interactive controls.
actual_capabilities: Creates a 4 to 6 paragraph algorithmic philosophy in markdown
Builds a single self contained HTML artifact using p5.js from CDN
Implements seeded randomness with randomSeed and noiseSeed
Defines parameter controls with sliders and live value displays
Includes seed navigation controls and reset behavior from the template
limitations: Requires p5.js to load from a CDN at runtime
HTML output must follow the provided viewer template structure
Does not generate static images without running the artifact
Quality depends on the clarity of the user intent

use_cases.title: Prototype a generative sketch
use_cases.description: Get a philosophy and a runnable HTML sketch to explore algorithmic ideas quickly.

use_cases.title: Teach creative coding concepts
use_cases.description: Show students how a concept becomes parameters and a reproducible system.

use_cases.title: Explore branded visual systems
use_cases.description: Generate seeded variations that align with a design direction and palette.

prompt_templates.title: Start a simple idea
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an algorithmic philosophy about gentle wind over sand and provide the HTML artifact with two simple parameters and a calm palette.

prompt_templates.title: Add theme constraints
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the concept of urban rhythms to build the philosophy and a p5.js artifact with parameters for density, speed, and contrast.

prompt_templates.title: Emphasize structure
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a philosophy about harmonic grids and deliver a self contained HTML sketch with seeded symmetry and controls for phase and spacing.

prompt_templates.title: Complex emergent system
prompt_templates.prompt: Develop a philosophy on recursive fields and generate the HTML artifact with particle interactions, multiple color controls, and precise parameter ranges.

output_examples.input: Create a philosophy about tidal currents and produce the interactive artifact with three parameters.
output: Algorithmic philosophy describing seeded flow, layered noise, and emergent currents
Single HTML artifact using the provided viewer template structure
Controls for particle count, flow speed, and noise scale with seed navigation

best_practices: Describe the intended motion or structure so parameters map to clear behaviors
Keep parameter ranges narrow enough to preserve visual quality
Use seeded randomness so results are reproducible and shareable
anti_patterns: Requesting a static image without running the HTML artifact
Asking to change the fixed template layout or branding
Using vague themes without any algorithmic direction

faq.question: Is this compatible with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code?
faq.answer: Yes. It produces plain markdown and HTML that these platforms can render or save.

faq.question: What are the output limits?
faq.answer: It produces one philosophy text and one self contained HTML artifact per request.

faq.question: Can I integrate the output into my site?
faq.answer: Yes. You can embed the HTML artifact or adapt the p5.js code to your site.

faq.question: Does it handle sensitive data?
faq.answer: No. Avoid sharing sensitive inputs because outputs are meant for public art artifacts.

faq.question: What if the artifact does not render?
faq.answer: Check that the browser can access the p5.js CDN and that the HTML is unmodified.

faq.question: How does this compare to generic art prompts?
faq.answer: It outputs reproducible algorithms with controls, not a single static image description.
